description: In this series viewers will be introduced to the basics of the interworking of a computer’s system hardware and the individual components. The series will also tackle the basics of a computer operating system, applications, utilities and navigation. Finally the viewer will be guided through the basics of networking. This series is intended to give an introductory demonstration of the computing environment that most will encounter in todays world.
name: IC3 Computing Fundamentals
subtitle: Global Standard 5

episodes.description: In this series viewers will be introduced to the basics of the interworking of a computer’s system hardware and the individual components. The series will also tackle the basics of a computer operating system, applications, utilities and navigation. Finally the viewer will be guided through the basics of networking. This series is intended to give an introductory demonstration of the computing environment that most will encounter in todays world.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes describe and discuss the basic mobile device uses:  As a personal cell phone, a voice mail system, a SMS system and even a notification system. They describe the device must be connected with a service provider for the usage of these system.  Wes also describes the it’s functionality as a phone and shows some of the components to manually setup the device to use the voice mail and notification systems as well.  The guys also briefly tell us some of the most common vendors of the phone hardware.
episodes.title: Mobile Devices

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes describe different types of computing hardware systems that users are likely to use in a work environment.  They discuss the nature of desktop computers and compare to mobile types like laptops and tablets.   Also discussed by the team is the use of servers, supercomputers and mainframes especially the context of their usage. They emphasize the most likely use of each type of hardware and where a user is most likely to encounter the them in their work environment.
episodes.title: Hardware Device Types

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes show and explain the the different hardware components found within the system unit.  They describe 64bit and 32 bit platforms as well as computing types:  PC and Apple based computers.  They also describe the basic units that must match in form factor:  the case, the motherboard and power supply unit.  They spend some time displaying the computer case and the features of the power supply unit.
episodes.title: Hardware Components

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes show and demonstrates some additional hardware components beginning with the motherboard and cpu.  They take the time to describe how each of these function and some attributes of how they’re rated for use.   They want to makes sure that we understand how the cpu, motherboard, ram and even expansion card help us to improve the system unit’s performance.
episodes.title: Hardware Components Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes talk about some of the most common out device peripherals users will use or see on a regular workday.  They discuss and describe display devices including CRTs, LCDs, LEDs and OLEDs too.  They talk about not only some of the properties but also the devices they are normally are used with or used on.  They also take a the time to describe some of the most common printing devices:  Laser printers, thermal printers and inject printers.  To connect these peripherals to the system unit are several different cabling technologies including serial, parallel, usb and some wireless including Wi-Fi and bluetooth.
episodes.title: Peripherals

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes take look at some of the different input devices that daily computer users in a work environment are likely to see and use.  They describe the concept and show the keyboard as the main input device.  Just as prolific as the keyboard is the computer mouse that they describe has giving us the ability to do point and click.  They display and discuss many of the other input devices that are out there and talk about when users are most likely to encounter them.
episodes.title: Peripherals Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes introduce some of the different storage devices.  They describe the difference between mechanical and solid state drives and discuss briefly the capacity of storage drives.  They also talk about optical drives and their application.  They end the episode, by taking a look at multiple different types of connectors you’re likely to see.
episodes.title: Storage

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes introduce operating systems architecture.  Here they show that there are several different operating systems that computer users will likely encounter.  They describe the major differences and also class them as desktop and/or server operating systems.  Lastly they describe some of the utilities and tools normally built into the operating system to keep the operating system maintained.
episodes.title: Computer Software Architecture

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes help us to understand the basic Windows 7 user interface.  They show the different elements of the Windows 7 interface.  They describe and demonstrate how to work with the desktop, desktop icons, start menu and some of the customization elements.  They help the user to understand how it works to the advantage of the user.
episodes.title: Configuration and Preferences

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes continue to show some of the other configurations that a Windows 7 user will need to understand.  They describe the need of user accounts.  Also, they discuss the purpose of the user account control to help with computer safety and security.  They finish the episode with other user customizations that are possible.
episodes.title: Configurations and Preferences Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wed take a look at file management.  The smallest amount of data that users store is called a file, regardless of the size or type of data, they tell us.  With this as a basic understanding, the user must understand that to work with files, we must understand the path (location of the data) on a hard drive and the idea of moving, copying and storing and creating files, they discuss.  They also point out the concept of using storage devices to house data files, must begin with file systems and even additional attributes that can configured on files.
episodes.title: File Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes introduce the basic networking concepts.  They classify networks by geography, types and access technologies.  They uses the terminology that users are likely to encounter when talking about the most generic network geography:  LAN, WAN and PAN.  Briefly they describe how devices must be uniquely identified if they are to communicate on a network.  Lastly, they describe some of the access methods that are used such as Wireless and wired as well as how to access the internet.  They also talk about the use of terms like SLAs too.
episodes.title: Networking

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes show us some of the different data and system protection tools available to the user.  They discuss the use of system restore and data backups  They also show how to create restore points and use restore points.  They also show using the Windows 7 backup to backup and restore as well.  They remind us that to protect data we must consider backups as part of that strategy.
episodes.title: Backup and Restore

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes describe the concept of cloud computing and how it effects the user.  They describe the different types of cloud computing services that are available.  Also they talk about some of the different services available for most end users.  They also talk about it’s importance to the computing world today and that most people use cloud services regardless of whether they know it or not.
episodes.title: Cloud Computing

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Wes introduce the basic computing security concepts.  They emphasize the importance of security implementations being goal oriented: Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability.  The discuss some of the different way to implement credentials: passwords, SSO and password managers.  Also they discuss connecting securely through your browser and how to see it or implement it.  Wes also mentions the purpose of the firewall for the computer user and demonstrate some of the settings within the Windows Firewall.
episodes.title: Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes demonstrate and explain some of the commonly used PC troubleshooting tools and methods in IT. Here they show you how to use built-in features found in the Windows operating system like UAC settings, Compatibility Mode, and Backup and Restore. They also explore potential causes/cures for the dreaded Blue Screen Of Death(BSOD) as well as tools like msconfig, Reliability Monitor, and Event Viewer.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Software

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue to demonstrate and explain some of the commonly used PC troubleshooting tools and methods in IT. They pick back up by showing you how to diagnose and repair slow application response and unresponsive apps using tools like the Performance Monitor, Task Manager, and Resource Monitor.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Software Part 2
